thread.title: Fund managers are holding the most cash since Lehman’s collapse
thread.title_full: Fund managers are holding the most cash since Lehman’s collapse - MarketWatch

author: By     Joseph Adinolfi
title: Fund managers are holding the most cash since Lehman’s collapse
text:
AFP/Getty Images Shown: Lehman Brothers headquarters in New York shortly before the investment bank’s bankruptcy in September 2008. Fund managers are holding the most cash since the collapse of Lehman Brothers because they’re reluctant to take on more risk as equity-market tumult in China and Greece’s potential exit from the eurozone threaten to weigh on global economic growth, according to a monthly survey of fund managers conducted by Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Managers are holding about 5.5% of their portfolios in cash, the highest level since December 2008. Lehman filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, sending shock waves through global financial markets.
Here’s the chart:
BAML Investors confidence in the global economy fell sharply, with 42% of survey participants expecting it to strengthen over the next year, down from 55% a month ago. China was viewed as the biggest risk to growth, with 62% expecting its economy to weaken over the same period.
They also tempered their expectations for the timing of the first Federal Reserve interest-rate increase since 2006. The consensus has shifted to the fourth quarter or later, from the third quarter or later in the June survey.
Investors also increased their exposure to global equities to 42% of their portfolios, from 38% last month—but many also hedged their short-term exposure. The percentage of investors buying protection against a decline in equities over the next three months rose to its highest level since February 2008.
Investors believed some of the biggest “tail risks”—events that are unlikely, but could trigger massive losses—were a eurozone breakup, a wave of debt defaults by Chinese enterprises and the fallout from a massive decline in Chinese equity prices.
The survey included feedback from 149 portfolio managers, and was conducted between July 2 and July 9.
